DIV1.P: THE MAYOR of GARRET. A COMEDY, In TWO ACTS. As it is PERFORMED at the THEATRE-ROYAL in DRURY-LANE. By SAMUEL FOOTE, Esq
LONDON: Printed for P. VAILLANT, facing Southampton-Street in the Strand. MDCCLXIV. (Price One Shilling.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. SCENE Sir JACOB's House at Garret.

SP.P: ROGER—
Anon, Sir—
Sir, sirrah! and why not Sir Jacob? You rascal, is that all your man∣ners. Has his majesty dubb'd me a Knight for you to make me a Mister. Are the can∣didates near upon coming?
Nic Goose the taylor from Putney, they say, will be here in a crack, Sir Jacob.
Has Margery fetch'd in the linen?
Yes, Sir Jacob.
Are the pigs and the poultry lock'd up in the barn?
Safe, Sir Jacob.
And the plate and spoons in the pantry?
Yes, Sir Jacob.
Then give me the key; the mob will soon be upon us: And all is fish that comes to their net. Has Ralph laid the cloth in the hall?
Yes, Sir Jacob.
Then let him bring out the turkey and chine, and be sure there is plenty of mustard; and, d'ye hear, Roger, do you stand yourself at the gate, and be careful who you let in.
I will, Sir Jacob.Exit Rog.
So, now I believe things are pretty secure: But I can't think what makes my daughters so late, ere they —
Who is that, Roger?
without.Master Lint, the potter-carrier, Sir Jacob.
Let him in. What the deuce can he want?
Well, master Lint, your will?
Why, I come, Sir Jacob, partly to enquire after your health; and partly, as I may say, to settle the business of the day.
What business?

Your worship knoweth, this being the day of election, the rabble may be riotous; in which case, maims, bruises, contusions, dislocations, fractures, simple and compound, may likely ensue; now your worship need not be told, that I am not on∣ly a pharmacopolist, or vender of drugs; but likewise chirurgeon, or healer of wounds.
True, master Lint, and equally skilful in both.
It is your worship's pleasure to say so, Sir Jacob: Is it your worship's will that I lend a ministring hand to the maim'd?
By all means.
And to whom must I bring in my bill?
Doubtless, the vestry.
Your worship knows, that kill or cure, I have contracted to physic the parish-poor by the great: But this must be a se∣parate charge.
No, no; all under one; come, master Lint, don't be unreasonable.
Indeed, Sir Jacob, I can hardly af∣ford it. What with the dearness of drugs, and the number of patients the peace has procured me, I can't get salt to my por∣ridge.
Bad this year, the better the next—We must take things rough and smooth as they run.
Indeed, I have a very hard bar∣gain.
No such matter; we are, neigh∣bour Lint, a little better instructed. For∣merly indeed, a fit of illness was very ex∣pensive; but now, physic is cheaper than food.
Marry, heaven forbid.

No, no, your essences, elixirs, emetics, sweats, drops, and your pastes, and your pills, have silenced your pestles and mortars. Why a fever, that would former∣ly have cost you a fortune, you may now cure for twelve pennorth of powder.
Or kill, Sir Jacob.
And then as to your scurvys, and gouts, rheumatisms, consumptions, coughs and catarrhs, tar-water and turpen∣tine will make you as sound as a roach.
Nostrums.
Specifics, specifics, master Lint.
I am very sorry to find a man of your worship's—Sir Jacob, a promoter of puffs; an encourager of quacks, Sir Jacob.
Regulars, Lint, regulars; look at their names, Roger, bring me the news not a soul of them but is either P. L. or M. D.
Plaugy liars! Murderous dogs!
Liars! Here, look at the list of their cures. The oath of Margery Squab, of Ratcliff-Highway, spinster.
Perjuries.
And see here, the churchwar∣dens have signed it.
Fictitious, Sir Jacob.
Sworn before the worshipful Mr. Justice Drowsy, this thirteenth day of——
Forgery.
Why, hark'ye, sirrah, do you think Mr. Justice Drowsey would set his hand to a forgery?
I know, Sir Jacob, that woman; she has been cured of fifty diseases in a fort∣night, and every one of 'em mortal.
You impudent——
Of a dropsy, by West——
Audacious—
A cancer, by Cleland.
Arrogant——
A palsy, by Walker——
Impertinent——
Gout and sciatic, by Rock——
Insolent——
Consumption, by Stevens's drops—
Paltry——
And squinting, by the Chevalier Taylor.
Pill-gilding puppy.
And as to the Justice, so the affida∣vit brings him a shilling——
Why, hark'ye, rascal, how dare you abuse the commission?—You blood-let∣ting, tooth-drawing, corn-cutting, worm-killing, blistering, glistering—
Bless me, Sir Jacob, I did not think to——
What, sirrah, do you insult me in my office: Here, Roger, out with him— Turn him out.
Sir, as I hope to be——

Away with him. You scoun∣drel, if my clerk was within, I'd send you this instant to Bridewell. Things are come to a pretty pass, indeed, if after all my read∣ing in Wood and Nelson and Burn; if after twenty years attendance at turnpike-meet∣ings, sessions, petty and quarter; if after settling of rates, licencing ale-houses, and committing of vagrants—But all respects to
authority is lost, and Unus Quoram now-a-days, is no more regarded than a petty constable. Knocking. Roger, see who is at the gate? Why the fellow is deaf.
Justice Sturgeon, the fishmonger, from Brentford.
God's my life! and Major to the Middlesex militia. Usher him in, Roger.
I could have wish'd you had come a little sooner, Major Sturgeon.
Why, what has been the matter, Sir Jacob?
There has, Major, been here an impudent pill-monger, who has dar'd to scandalize the whole body of the bench.
Insolent companion! had I been here, I would have mittimus'd the rascal at once.

No, no, he wanted the Major more than the magistrate; a few smart strokes from your cane would have fully an∣swer'd the purpose.—Well, Major, our wars are done; the rattling drum, and squeaking fife, now wound our ears no more.
True, Sir Jacob, our corps is dis∣embodied, so the French may sleep in se∣curity.
But, Major, was it not rather late in life for you, to enter upon the profes∣sion of arms?

A little aukward in the begin∣ning, Sir Jacob: The great difficulty they had was, to get me to turn out my toes; but use, use reconciles all them kind of things: Why, after my first campaign, I no more minded the noise of the guns than a flea-bite.
No!
No. There is more made of these matters than they merit. For the ge∣neral good indeed, I am glad of the peace; but as to my single self——And yet, we have had some desperate duty, Sir Jacob.
No doubt.

Oh! such marchings and coun∣ter-marchings from Brentford to Elin, from Elin to Acton, from Acton to Uxbridge: The dust flying, sun scorching, men sweat∣ting—Why, there was our last expedition to Hounslow, that day's work carried off Major Molossas. Bunhill-fields never saw a braver commander. He was an irreparable loss to the service.
How came that about?
Why, it was partly the Major's own fault; I advised him to pull off his spurs before he went upon action; but he was resolute, and would not be rul'd.
Spirit; zeal for the service.

Doubtless—But to proceed: In order to get our men in good spirits, we were quarter'd at Thistleworth the evening before; at day-break, our regiment form'd at Hounslow town's-end, as it might be about here. The Major made a fine disposi∣tion: On we marched, the men all in high spirits, to attack the gibbet where Gardel is hanging; but turning down a narrow lane to the left, as it might be about there, in order to possess a pig's-stye, that we might take the gallows in flank, and, at all events, secure a retreat; who should come by but a drove of fat oxen for Smithfield. The drums beat in the front, the dogs bark'd in the rear, the oxen set up a gallop; on they came thundering upon us; broke through our ranks in an instant, and threw the whole corps in confusin.
Terrible!

The Major's horse took to his heels, away he scour'd over the heath. That gallant commander stuck both his spurs into the flank, and for some time held by his mane; but in crossing a ditch, the horse threw up his head, gave the Major a dowse in the chops, and plump'd him into a gravel-pit, just by the powder-mills.
Dreadful!
Whether from the fall or the fright, the Major mov'd off in a month— Indeed it was an unfortunate day for us all.
As how?

Why, as Captain Cucumber, Lieutenant Patty-Pan, Ensign Tripe, and myself, were returning to town in the Turnham-Green stage, we were stop'd near the Hammersmith turnpike, and rob'd and stripp'd by a footpad.
An unfortunate day indeed.
But in some measure to make me amends, I got the Major's commission.
You did.

O yes. I was the only one of the corps that could ride; otherwise, we al∣ways succeeded of course: No jumping over heads; no underhand work among us; all men of honour; and I must do the regi∣ment the justice to say, thre never was a set of more amiable officers.
Quiet and peaceable.
As lambs, Sir Jacob, (excepting one boxing-bout at the Three-Compasses in Acton, between Captain Sheers and the Colonel, concerning a game at All-fours) I don't remember a single dispute.
Why, that was mere mutiny; the Captain ought to have been broke.

He was; for the Colonel not on∣ly took away his cockade, but his custom;
and I dont think poor Captain Sheers has done a stitch for him since.
But you soon supplied the loss of Molossas?

In part only; no, Sir Jacob, he had great experience; he was train'd up to arms from his youth: At sixteen he trail'd a pike in the Artillery-ground; at eighteen got a company in the Smithfield pioneers; and by the time he was twenty, was made aid-de-camp to Sir Jeffery Grub, Knight, Alderman, and Colonel of the Yellow.
A rapid rise!

Yes, he had a genius for war; but what I wanted in practice, I made up by doubling my diligence. Our porter at home had been a serjeant of marines; so af∣ter shop was shut up at night, he us'd to teach me my exercise; and he had not to deal with a dunce, Sir Jacob.
Your progress was great.
Amazing. In a week I could shoulder, and rest, and poize, and turn to the right, and wheel to the left; and in less than a month, I could fire without winking or blinking.
A perfect Hannibal!

Ah, and then I learnt to form lines, and hollows, and squares, and evolu∣tions, and revolutions; let me tell you, Sir Jacob, it was lucky that Monsieur kept his
mirmidons at home, or we should have pep∣per'd his flat-bottom'd boats.
Ay, marry, he had a marvellous escape.
We would a taught him what a Brton can do who is fighting pro arvis and focus.
Pray now, Major, which do you look upon as the best disciplin'd troops, the London regiments, or the Middlesex militia?

Why, Sir Jacob, it does not be∣come to me say; but lack-a-day, they have never seen any service—Holiday soldiers; why, I don't believe, unless indeed upon a lord-mayor's day, and that mere matter of accident, that they were ever wet to the skin in their lives.
Indeed!
No! soldiers for sun-shine, Cock∣neys; they have not the appearance, the air, the freedom, the Jenny sequi that— Oh, could you but see me salute: You have never a spontoon in the house?
No; but we could get you a shove-pike.
No matter. Well, Sir Jacob, and how are your fair daughters, sweet Mrs. Sneak, and the lovely Mrs. Bruin, is she as lively and as brilliant as ever?

Oh, oh, now the murder is out; this visit was intended for them; come, own
now, Major, did not you expect to meet with them here? You officers are men of such gallantry!
Why, we do tickle up the ladies, Sir Jacob; there is no resisting a red coat.
True, true, Major.

But that is now all over with me. “Farewel to the plumed steeds and neigh∣ing ”troops, as the black man says in the play; like the Roman censurer, I shall re∣tire to my savine field, and there cultivate cabbages.
Under the shade of your laurels.
True, I have done with the Ma∣jor, and now return to the magistrate, Ce∣dunt Arma Togge.
Still in the service of your country.
True; man was not made for himself; and so, thinking that this would prove a busy day in the justicing way, I am come, Sir Jacob, to lend you a hand.
Done like a neighbour.
I have brought, as I suppose most of our business will be in the battery way, some warrants and mittimuses ready fill'd up, with all but the names of the parties, in order to save time.
A provident magistrate.
Pray, how shall we manage as to the article of swearing; for I reckon we shall have oaths as plenty as hops.
Why, with regard to that branch of our business, to-day, I believe, the law must be suffer'd to sleep.
I should think we might pick up something that's pretty that way.
No, poor rascals, they would not be able to pay; and as to the stocks, we should never find room for their legs.
Pray, Sir Jacob, is Matthew Mar∣row-bone the butcher of your town, living or dead?
Living.
And swears as much as he used?
An alter'd man, Major; not an oath comes out of his mouth.
You surprize me; why, when he frequented our town of a market-day, he has taken out a guinea in oaths—and quite chang'd?
Entirely; they say his wife has made him a Methodist, and that he preaches at Kennington-Common.
What a deal of mischief those rascals do in the country—Why then we have entirely lost him?
In that way; but I got a brace of bind-overs from him last week for a cou∣ple of bastards.
Well done, master Matthew— but pray now, Sir Jacob—
What's the matter now, Roger?
The electors desire to know, if your worship has any body to recommend?
By no means; let them be free in their choice: I shan't interfere.
And if your worship has any ob∣jection to Crispin Steel-Tap, the Cobler's being returning officer?
None, provided the rascal can keep himself sober: Is he there?
Yes, Sir Jacob: Make way there; stand farther off from the gate: Here is Madam Sneak in a chair, along with her husband.
Gad's so, you will permit me to convoy her in?Exit Major.

Now here is one of the evils of war. This Sturgeon was as pains-taking a Billingsgate-broker, as any in the bills of mortality. But the fish is got out of his element; the soldier has quite demolish'd the citizen.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. SNEAK, handed by the MAJOR.

SP.P: Dear Major, I demand a million of pardons. I have given you a profusion of trouble; but my husband is such a goose-cap, that I cant get no good out of him at home or abroad.—Jerry, Jerry Sneak—Your blessing, Sir Jacob.
Daughter, you are welcome to Garret.
Why, Jerry Sneak, I say.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter SNEAK with a band-box, a hoop-petticoat under his arm, and cardinal, &c. &c. &c. &c.

SP.P: Here, lovy.
Here, looby: there, lay these things in the hall; and then go and look after the horse: Are you sure you have got all the things out of the chaise?
Yes, chuck.
Then give me my fan.

STAGE.HI: Jerry drops the things in searching his pocket for the fan.

SP.P: Did ever mortal see such a— I declare, I am quite asham'd to be seen with him abroad: Go, get you gone out of my sight.
I go, lovy: Good day to my fa∣ther-in-law.
I am glad to see you, son Sneak: But where is your brother Bruin and his wife?
He will be here anon, father. Sir Jacob, he did but just step into the Alley to gather how tickets were sold.
Very well, son Sneak.
Son! yes, and a pretty son you have provided.
I hope all for the best: Why, what terrible work there would have been, had you married such a one as your sister; one house could never have contain'd you— Now, I thought this meek mate—
Meek! a mushroom! a milk-sop!
Lookye, Molly, I have married you to a man: Take care you don't make him a monster.Exit Sir Jac.
Monster! Why, Major, the fellow has no more heart than a mouse: Had my kind stars indeed, allotted me a military man, I should, doubtless, have de∣ported myself in a beseemingly manner.
Unquestionably, madam.
Nor would the Major have found, had it been my fortune to intermar∣ry with him, that Molly Jollup would have dishonoured his cloth.
I should have been too happy.
Indeed, Sir, I reverence the army; they are all so brave; so polite; so every thing a woman can wish.
Oh! Madam—
So elegant; so genteel; so obliging: and then the rank; why, who would dare to affront the wife of a Major?
No man with impunity; that I take the freedom to say, madam.
I know it, good Sir: Oh! I am no stranger to what I have miss'd.
Oh, madam!—Let me die, but she has infinite merit.Aside.
Then to be join'd to a sneak∣ing slovenly cit; a paltry, prying, pitiful pin-maker.
Melancholy.
To be jostled and cram'd with the croud: No respect, no place, no precedence; to be choak'd with the smoak of the city: No country jaunts, but to Isling∣ton; No balls, but at Pewterer's-hall.
Intolerable.
I see, Sir, you have a pro∣per sense of my sufferings.
And would shed my best blood to relieve them.
Gallant gentleman!
The brave must favour the fair.
Intrepid Major!
Divine Mrs. Sneak!
Obliging commander!
Might I be permitted the ho∣nour——
Sir—
Just to ravish a kiss from your hand.
You have a right to all we can grant.
Courteous, condescending, com∣plying—Hum—Ha!
Chuck, my brother and sister Bruin are just turning the corner; the Clapham stage was quite full, and so they came by water.
I wish they had all been sous'd in the Thames—A prying, imperti∣nent puppy!
Next time, I will clap a centinel to secure the door.
Major Sturgeon, permit me to withdraw for a moment; my dress de∣mands a little repair.
Your ladyship's most entirely de∣voted.
Ladyship! he is the very Broglio and Bellisle of the army!
Shall I wait upon you, dove?
No, dolt; what, would you leave the Major alone; is that your manners, you mongrel.
Oh, madam, I can be never alone; your sweet idera will be my constant com∣panion.
Mark that: I am sorry, Sir, I am obligated to leave you.
Madam—
Especially with such a wretche dcompanion.
Oh, madam—
But as soon as my dress is restor'd, I shall fly to relieve your distress.
For that moment I shall wait with the greatest impatience.
Courteous commander.
Barragon of women!
Adieu!
Adieu!Exit Mrs. Sneak.
Notwithstanding, Sir, all my chicken has said, I am special company when she is not by.
I doubt not, master Sneak.

If you would but come one Thurs∣day-night to our club, at the Nagg's-Head in the Poultry, you would meet some roar∣ing, rare boys, i'faith: There's Jemmy Per∣kins, the packer; little Tom Simkins, the grocer; honest Master Muzzle, the mid∣wife——
A goodly company!

Ay, and then sometimes we have the Choice Spirits from Comus's Court, and we crack jokes, and are so jolly and funny: I have learnt myself to sing “An old wo∣man ”cloathed in grey. But I durst not out loud, because my wife would overhear me; and she says, as how, I bawl worser than the broom man.
And you must not think of dis∣obliging your lady.
I never does: I never contradicts her, not I.
That's right: she is a woman of infinite merit.
O, a power: And don't you think she is very pretty withal?
A Venus!
Yes, werry like Wenus—Mayhap, you have known her some time?
Long.
Belike, before she was married?
I did, Master Sneak.
Ay, when she was a wirgin. I thought you was an old acquaintance, by your kissing her hand; for we ben't quite so familiar as that—But then, indeed, we han't been married a year.
The mere honey-moon.
Ay, ay, I suppose we shall come to it by degrees.
withinCome along, Jane; why, you are as pursy and lazy, you jade—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter BRUIN, and WIFE; BRUIN with a cotton-cap on; his Wife with his wig, great-coat, and fishing-rod.

SP.P: Come, Jane, give me my wig; you slut, how you have tousled the curls? Master Sneak, a good morning to you: Sir, I am your humble servant, unknown.
Mrs. Sneak begs to speak with the Major.
I will wait on the lady imme∣diately.
Don't tarry an instant; you can't think how impatient she is.
A good morrow to you, brother Bruin; you have had a warm walk cross the fields.
Good lord, I am all in a muck——
And who may you thank for it, hussy? If you had got up time enough, you might have secur'd the stage; but you are a lazy lie-a-bed.
There's Mr. Sneak keeps my sister a chay.

And so he may; but I know bet∣ter what to do with my money: Indeed, if the war had but continued awhile, I don't know what mought ha been done; but this plagy peace, with a pox to't, has knock'd up all the trade of the Alley.
For the matter of that, we can afford it well enough as it is.

And how do you know that? Who told you as much, Mrs. Mixen: I hope I know the world better than to trust my
concerns with a wife: No, no, thank you for that, Mrs. Jane.
And pray, who is more fit∣terer to be trusted?

Hey-day! Why, the wench is bewitched: Come, come, let's have none of your palaver here—Take twelve-pence and pay the waterman.—But first see, if he has broke none of the pipes—And, d'ye hear, Jane, besure you lay the fishing-rod safe.Exit Mrs. Bruin.
Ods me, how finely she's manag'd; what would I give to have my wife as much under.
It is all your own fault, brother Sneak.
D'ye think so; she is a sweet pretty creature.
A vixen.

Why, to say the truth, she does now and then hector a little; and, between ourselves, domineers like the devil: O Lord, I lead the life of a dog: Why, she allows me but two shillings a week for my pocket.
No!
No, man; 'tis she that receives and pays all: And then I am forc'd to trot after her to church, with her cardinal, pat∣tens, and prayer-book, for all the world as if I was still a 'prentice.
Zounds! I would souse them all in the kennel.
I durst not—And then at table, I never gets what I loves.
The devil!

No; she always helps me herself to the tough drumsticks of turkeys, and the damn'd fat flaps of shoulders of mutton; I don't think I have eat a bit of under-crust since we have been married: You see, bro∣ther Bruin, I am almost as thin as a lath.
An absolute skeleton!
Now, if you think I could carry my point, I would so swinge and leather my lambkin: God, I would so curry and claw her.
By the Lord Harry, she richly deserves it.
Will you, brother, lend me a lift?
Command me at all times.
Why then, I will verily pluck up a spirit; and the first time she offers to—
withinJerry, Jerry Sneak!
Gad's my life, sure as a gun that's her voice: Look'ye, brother, I don't chuse to breed a disturbance in another body's house; but as soon as ever I get home—
Now is your time.
No, no; it would not be decent.
withinJerry! Jerry! —
I come, lovy. But you will be sure to stand by me?
Trot, nincompoop.
Well, if I don't—I wish—
withinWhere is this lazy puppy, a-loitering?
I come, chuck, as fast I can— Good Lord, what a sad life do I lead.
Ex quovis ligno: Who can make a silk purse of a sow's ear?
Come, son Bruin, we are all seated at table, man; we have but just time for a snack: The candidates are near upon coming.
A poor, paltry, mean spirited— Damn it, before I would submit to such a—
Come, come, man; don't be so crusty.

I follow, Sir Jacob: Damme, when once a man gives up his perogative, he might as well give up—But, however, it is no bread and butter of mine——Jerry, Jerry,—Zounds, I would Jerry and jerk her to.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Continues.
DIV3.STAGE: Sir JACOB, Major STURGEON; Mr. and Mrs. BRUIN; Mr. and Mrs. SNEAK, discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SNEAK.
SP.P: INDEED, Major, not a grain of curio∣sity; can it be thought, that we, who have a Lord-Mayor's show every year, can take any pleasure in this?
In time of war, madam, these meetings are not amiss; I fancy, a man might pick up a good many recruits: But in these piping times of peace, I wonder Sir Jacob permits it.
It would, Major, cost me my popularity to quash it: The common peo∣ple are as fond of their customs, as the ba∣rons were of their Magna Charta: Besides, my tenants make some little advantage.
Crispin Heel-tap, with the electors, are set out from the Adam and Eve.
God-so, then they will soon be upon us: Come, good folks, the balcony will give us the best view of the whole. Major, you will take the ladies under pro∣tection.
Sir Jacob, I am upon guard.
I can tell you, this Heel-tap is an arch rascal.
And plays the best game at crib∣bage in the whole corporation of Garret.
That puppy will always be a chattering.
Nay, I did but——
Hold your tongue, or I'll send you home in an instant——
Pry'thee, daughter: You may to-day, Major, meet with something that will put you in mind of more important transactions.
Perhaps so.
Lack-a-day, all men are alike; their principles exactly the same: for tho' art and education may disguise or polish the manner, the same motives and springs are universally planted.
Indeed!

Why, in this mob, this group of plebeans, you will meet with materials to make a Sylla, a Cicero, a Solon, or a Caesar: Let them but change conditions, and the world's great lord had been but the best wrestler on the green.
Ay, ay, I could have told these things formerly; but since I have been in the army, I have entirely neglected the classes.
But the heroes are at hand, Major.
Father, Sir Jacob: Might not we have a tankard of stingo above?
By all means.
D'ye hear, Roger?

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, A STREET.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter MOB, with HEEL-TAP at their head; some crying a Goose; others a Mug; others a Primmer.

SP.P: Silence, there; silence.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Mob.
SP.P: Hear, neighbour Heel-Tap.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Mob.
SP.P: Ay, ay, hear, Crispin.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: Ay, ay, hear him, hear Crispin: He will put us into the model of the thing at once.
Why then, silence, I say.
Silence.
Silence, and let us proceed, neighbours, with all the decency and con∣fusion usual upon these occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Mob.
SP.P: Ay, ay, there is no doing with∣out that.
No, no, no.
Silence then, and keep the peace; what, is there no respect paid to au∣thority: Am not I the returning officer?
Ay, ay, ay.
Chosen by yourselves, and ap∣proved of by Sir Jacob.
True, true.
Well then, be silent and civil: Stand back there, that gentleman without a shirt, and make room for your betters: Where's Simon Snuffle the Sexton?
Here.
Let him come forward; we appoint him our secretary: For Simon is a scollard, and can read written hand; and so let him be respected accordingly.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: Room, for Master Snuffle.

Here, stand by me: and let us, neighbours, proceed to open the premunire of the thing: But first, your reverence to the lord of the manor; a long life and a merry one to our landlord, Sir Jacob; huzza!
Huzza!
How fares it, honest Crispin?

Servant, Master Sneak: Let us now open the premunire of the thing, which, I shall do briefly, with all the loqua∣city possible; that is, in a medium way; which, that we may the better do it, let the secretary read the names of the candidates,
and what they say for themselves; and then we shall know what to say of them: Master Snuffle, begin.

P.Q: “To the worthy inhabitants of the ancient corporation of Garret: Gen∣tlemen, your votes and interest are hum∣bly requested in favour of Timothy Goose, to succeed your late worthy mayor, Mr. Richard Dripping, in the ”said office, he being——

SP.P: This Goose is but a kind of Gosling, a sort of sneaking scoundrel, who is he?
A journeyman taylor, from Put∣ney.

A journeyman taylor! A rascal, has he the impudence to transpire to be mayor? D'ye consider, neighbours, the weight of this office? Why, it is a burthen for the back of a porter; and can you think that this cross-leg'd cabbage-eating son of a cucumber, this whey-fac'd ninny, who is but the ninth part of a man, has strength to support it?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Mob.
SP.P: No Goose! no Goose!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Mob.
SP.P: A Goose!
Hold your hissing, and pro∣ceed to the next.
Your votes are desired for Mat∣thew Mug.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Mob.
SP.P: A Mug! A Mug!

Oh, oh, what you are all ready to have a touch of the tankard: But, fair and soft, good neighbours, let us taste this Master Mug, before we swallow him; and, unless I am mistaken, you will find him a damn'd bitter draught.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Mob.
SP.P: A Mug! A Mug!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Mob.
SP.P: Hear him; hear Master Heel-Tap?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Mob.
SP.P: A Mug! A Mug!
Harkye, you fellow, with your mouth full of Mug, let me ask you a ques∣tion: Bring him forward; pray, is not this Matthew Mug a victualer?

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: I believe he may.
And lives at the sign of the Adam and Eve?

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: I believe he may.
Now answer upon your ho∣nour, and as you are a gentleman, what is the present price of a quart of home-brew'd at the Adam and Eve?

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: I don't know.
You lie, sirrah: An't it a groat?

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: I believe it may.

Oh, may it so: Now, neigh∣bours, here's a pretty rascal; this same Mug, because, d'ye see, state-affairs would not jog glibly without laying a farthing a quart upon ale; this scoundrel, not content∣ed to take things in a medium way, has had the impudence to raise it a penny.
No Mug, no Mug.
So, I thought I should crack Mr. Mug. Come, proceed to the next, Simon.
The next upon the list is Peter Primmer, the school-master.

Ay, neighbours, and a suffi∣cient man: Let me tell you, Master Prim∣mer is the man for my money; a man of learning; that can lay down the law; why, adzooks, he is wise enough to puzzle the parson: And then, how you have heard him oration at the Adam and Eve of a Saturday-night, about Russia and Prussia: Ecod, George Gage the exciseman, is no∣thing at all to un.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: A Primmer.
Ay, if the folks above did but know him; why, lads, he will make us all statesmen in time.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Mob.
SP.P: Indeed!
Why, he swears, as how all the miscarriages are owing to the great peo∣ple's not learning to read.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: Indeed!
For, says Peter, says he, if they would but once submit to be learned by me, there is no knowing to what a pitch the nation might rise.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Mob.
SP.P: Ay, I wish they would.
Crispin, what is Peter Primmer a candidate?
He is, Master Sneak.
Lord, I know him, mun, as well my mother: Why, I used to go to his lec∣tures to Pewterer's-hall 'long with deputy Firkin.
Like enough.
Ods me, brother Bruin, can you tell what is become of my vife?
She is gone off with the Major.
Mayhap, to take a walk in the gar∣den; I will go and take a peep at what they are doing.Exit Sneak.
Gadso! the candidates are coming. Come, neighbours, range your∣selves to the right and left, that you may be convas'd in order: Let us see who comes first?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Mob.
SP.P: Master Mug.
Now, neighbours, have a good caution that this Master Mug does not ca∣jole you; he is a damn'd palavering fellow.
Gentlemen, I am the lowest of your slaves: Mr. Heel-Tap, I have the ho∣nour of kissing your hand.
There, did not I tell you.
Ah, my very good friend, I hope your father is well?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Mob.
SP.P: He is dead.
So he is. Mr. Grub, if my wishes prevail, your very good wise is in health.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Mob.
SP.P: Wife! I never was married.
No more you were. Well, neigh∣bours and friends—Ah! what honest Dick Bennet.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: My name is Gregory Gubbins.
You are right, it is so; and how fares it with good Master Gubbins?

SP.SPEAKER: 3d. Mob.
SP.P: Pretty tight, Master Mug.
I am exceedingly happy to hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: Hark'ye, Master Mug.
Your pleasure, my very dear friend,

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: Why as how, and concerning our young one at home.
Right, she is a prodigious promis∣ing girl.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: Girl! Zooks, why, 'tis a boy.
True, a fine boy; I love and ho∣nour the child.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis none such a child; but you promis'd to get un a place.
A place! what place?

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: Why, a gentleman's service you know.
It is done; it is fix'd; it is settled.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th Mob.
SP.P: And when is the lad to take on?
He must go in a fortnight at farthest.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: And is it a pretty goodish birth, Master Mug?
The best in the world; head-but∣ler to lady Barbara Bounce.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: A lady!
The wages are not much, but the vails are amazing.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: Barbara Bunch.
Yes; she has routs on Tuesdays and Sundays, and he gathers the tables; on∣ly he finds candles, cards, coffee, and tea.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: Is Lady Barbara's work pretty tight?
As good as a sine-cure; he only writes cards to her company▪ and dresses his mistress's hair.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: Hair! Zounds, why Jack was bred to dressing of horses.
True, but he is suffered to do that by deputy.

SP.SPEAKER: 4th. Mob.
SP.P: May be so.
It is so. Hark'ye, dear Heel-Tap, who is this fellow, I should remember his face?
And don't you?
Not I, I profess.
No!
No.
Well said, Master Mug; but come, time wears: Have you any thing more to say to the corporation?
Gentlemen of the corporation of Garret.
Now, twig him; now, mind him: mark how he hawls his muscles about.

The honour I this day solicit, will be to me the most honourable honour that can be conferr'd; and, should I succeed, you, gentlemen, may depend on my using my utmost endeavours to promote the good of the borough; for which purpose, the en∣couragement of your trade and manufacto∣ries will most principally tend. Garret, it must be own'd, is an inland town, and has not, like Wandsworth, and Fulham, and Putney, the glorious advantages of a port; but what nature has denied, industry may supply: Cabbage, carrots, and colly-flowers, may be at present deem'd your staple com∣modities, but why should not your com∣merce be extended? Were I, gentlemen, worthy to advise, I would recommend the opening a new branch of trade; sparagrass, gentlemen, the manufacturing of sparagrass: Battersea, I own, gentlemen, bears at present the belle: But where lies the fault? In our∣selves, gentlemen: Let us, gentlemen, but exert our natural strength, and I will take upon me to say, that a hundred of grass from the corporation of Garret, will in a short time, at the London market, be held, at least, as an equivalent to a Battersea bundle.
A Mug! a Mug!
Damn the Fellow, what a tongue he has: God, I must step in, or he will carry the day. Harkee, Master Mug?
Your pleasure, my very good friend?
No flummering me: I tell thee, Matthew, 'twont do: Why, as to this article of ale here, how comes it about, that you have rais'd it a penny a quart?
A word in your ear, Crispin; you and your friends shall have it at three-pence.
What, sirrah, d'ye offer a bribe! D'ye dare to corrupt me, you scound∣rel!
Gentlemen—
Here, neighbours; the fellow has offer'd to bate a penny a quart, if so be as how I would be consenting to impose upon you.
No Mug! no Mug!
Neighbours, friends——
No Mug!
I believe this is the first borough that ever was lost, by the returning-officer's refusing a bribe.Exit Mug.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Mob.
SP.P: Let us go and pull down his sign.
Hold, hold, no riot: But that we may not give Mug time to pervert the votes and carry the day, let us proceed to the election.
Agreed! agreed!

STAGE.HI: Sir Jacob, Bruin, and Wife, come from the balcony.

SP.P: Well, son Bruin, and how d'ye relish the Corporation of Garret?
Why, look'ye, Sir Jacob; my way is always to speak what I think: I don't approve on't at all.
No!
And what's your objection?
Why, I was never over-fond of your may-games; besides, corporations are too serious things; they are edge-tools, Sir Jacob.
That they are frequently tools, I can readily grant; but I never heard much of their edge.
Well, now, I protest, I am pleas'd with it mightily.
And who the devil doubts it: You women folks are easily pleas'd.
Well, I like it so well, that I hope to see one every year.
Do you: Why then you will be damnably bit; you may take your leave I can tell you, for this is the last you shall see.
Fye, Mr. Bruin, how can you be such a bear: is that a manner of treat∣ing your wife?
What, I suppose you would have me such a sniveling sot as your son-in-law Sneak, to truckle and cringe, to fetch and to—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter SNEAK, in a violent hurry.

SP.P: Where's brother Bruin? O Lord, brother, I have such a dismal story to tell you.
What's the matter?

Why, you know I went into the garden to look for my wife and the Major, and there I hunted and hunted as sharp as if it had been for one of my own minickens; but the deuce a Major or Madam could I see: At last, a thought come into my head to look for them up in the summer-house.
And there you found them?
I'll tell you, the door was lock'd; and then I look'd thro' the key-hole: And, there, Lord a mercy upon us: Whispers as sure as a gun.
Indeed! Zounds, why did not you break open the door?
I durst not: What, would you have me set my wit to a soldier? I warrant, the Major would have knock'd me down with one of his boots; for I could see they were both of them off.

Very well! Pretty doings! You see, Sir Jacob, these are the fruits of in∣dulgence;
you may call me bear, but your daughter shall never make me a beast.
Hey-day? What is the election over already?
Where is Master Sneak?
Here, Crispin.
The ancient Corporation of Garret, in consideration of your great parts and abilities, and out of respect to their landlord, Sir Jacob, have unanimously chos∣en you mayor.
Me! huzza! good Lord, who would have thought it: But how come Master Primmer to lose it?
Why, Phill Fleam had told the electors, that Master Primmer was an Irishman; and so they would none of them give their vote for a foreigner.
So then, I have it for certain: Huzza! Now, brother Bruin, you shall see how I'll manage my Madam: Gad, I'll make her know I am a man of authority; she shan't think to bullock and domineer over me.
Now for it, Sneak; the enemy's at hand.
You promise to stand by me, bro∣ther Bruin.
Tooth and nail.
Then now for it; I am ready, let her come when she will.
Where is the puppy?
Yes, yes, she is axing for me.
So, sot; what, is this true that I hear?
May be 'tis, maybe 'tant: I don't chuse to trust my affairs with a voman: Is that right, brother Bruin?
Fine! don't bate her an inch.
Stand by me.
Hey-day! I am amaz'd! Why, what is the meaning of this?
The meaning is plain, that I am grown a man, and vill do what I please, without being accountable to nobody.
Why, the fellow is surely bewitch'd.
No, I am unwitch'd, and that you shall know to your cost; and since you pro∣voke me, I will tell you a bit of my mind: What, I am the husband I hope?
That's right; at her again.

Yes; and you shan't think to hector and domineer over me as you have done; for I'll go to the club when I please, and stay cut as late as I list, and row in a boat to Putney on Sundays, and wisit my
friends at Vitsontide, and keep the key of the till, and help myself at table to vhat vittles I like, and I'll have a bit of the brown.
Bravo, brother Sneak; the day's your own.
An't it; vhy, I did not think it vas in me; shall I tell her all I know?
Every thing; you see she is struck dumb.

As an oyster: Besides, madam, I have something furder to tell you: Ecod, if som folks go into gardens with Majors; mayhap other people may go into garrets with maids: There, I gave it her home, brother Bruin.
Why, doodle; jackanapes; harkee, who am I?
Come, don't go to call names: am I, vhy my vife, and I am your master.
My Master! you paltry, pudling puppy; you sneaking, shabby, scrub∣by, snivelling whelp.
Brother Bruin, don't let her come near me.

Have I, sirrah, demean'd myself to wed such a thing, such a reptile as thee: Have not I made myself a bye-word to all my acquaintance; don't all the world cry, Lord, who would have thought it. Miss Molly Jollup to be married to Sneak, to take up at last with such a noodle as he.
Ay, and glad enough you could catch me: You know, you was pretty near your last legs.

Was there ever such a confi∣dent cur. My last legs; why, all the coun∣try knows, I could have pick'd and chus'd where I would: Did not I refuse Squire Ap-Griffith from Wales; did not Counsel∣lor Crab come a courting a twelvemonth; did not Mr. Wort, the great brewer of Brentford, make an offer that I mould keep my post-chay.
Nay, brother Bruin, she has had werry good proffers, that is certain.
My last legs; but I can rein my passion no longer: Let me get at the villain.
O fye, sister Sneak.
Hold her fast.
Mr. Bruin, unhand me: What, it is you that have stir'd up these coals then; he is set on by you to abuse me.
Not I; I would only have a man behave like a man.
What, and you are to teach him, I warrant—But here comes the Major.

Oh Major! such a riot and rumpus! like a man indeed! I wish people would mind their own affairs, and not meddle with
matters that does not concern them: But all in good time; I shall one day catch him alone when he has not his bullies to back him.
Adod, that's true, brother Bruin; what shall I do when she has me at home, and nobody by but ourselves?
If you get her once under, you may do with her whatever you will.
Look'ye, Master Bruin, I don't know how this behaviour may suit with a citizen, but, were you an officer, and Major Sturgeon upon your court-marshal——
What then?
Then! why then you would be broke.
Broke! and for what?
What! read the articles of war: but these things are out of your spear: points of honour are for the sons of the sword.
Honour! if you come to that, where was your honour when you got my vife in the garden?
Now, Sir Jacob, this is the curse of our cloth: All suspected for the faults of a few.
Ay, and not without reason; I heard of your tricks at the King of Bohemy, when you was campaining about, I did: father, Sir Jacob, he is as vicious as an old ram.
Stop whilst you are safe, Master Sneak; for the sake of your amiable lady, I pardon what is past—But for you—
Well.
Dread the whole force of my fury.
Why, look'ye, Major Sturgeon, I don't much care for your poppers and sharpes, because why, they are out of my way; but if you will doff with your boots, and box a couple of bouts.
Box! box! blades! bullets! Bag∣shot!

Not for the world, my dear Major; oh, risk not so precious a life: Un∣grateful wretches, and is this the reward for all the great feats he has done: After all his marchings, his sousings, his sweat∣ings, his swimmings; must his dear blood be spilt by a broker!

Be satisfy'd, sweet Mrs. Sneak; these little fracases, we soldiers are subject to; trifles, bagatailes, Mrs. Sneak: But that matters may be conducted in a military man∣ner, I will get our chaplain to pen me a challenge. Expect to hear from my ad∣jutant.

Major, Sir Jacob; what, are you all leagu'd against his dear——A man; yes, a very manly action indeed, to set mar∣ried people a quarrelling, and ferment a dif∣ference between husband and wife; if you
were a man, you would not stand by and see a poor woman beat and abus'd by a brute, you would not.
Oh Lord, I can hold out no lon∣ger; why, brother Bruin, you have set her a veeping: My life, my lovy, don't veep: Did I ever think I should have made my Molly to veep.
Last legs; you lubberly—
Oh, fye! Molly.
What, are you leagu'd against me, Sir Jacob?
Prithee, don't expose yourself before the whole parish: But what has been the occasion of this.
Why has not he gone and made himself the fool of the fair: Mayor of Garret, indeed! ecod, I could trample him under my feet.
Nay, why should you grudge me my purfarment?
Did you ever hear such an oaff; why thee wilt be pointed at wherever thee goest: Look'ye, Jerry, mind what I say; go, get 'em to chose somebody else, or never come near me again.
What shall I do father, Sir Jacob?

Nay, daughter, you take this thing in too serious a light; my honest neighbours thought to compliment me: But come, we'll settle the business at once.
Neighbours, my son Sneak being seldom amongst us, the duty will never be done, so we wll get our honest friend Heel-Tap to execute the office; he is, I think, every way qualified.
A Heel-Tap!
What d'ye mean, as Master Jeremy's deputy?
Ay, ay, his Locum Tenens.
Do, Crispin; do be my Locum Tenens.
Give me your hand, Master Sneak, and to oblige you, I will be the Locum Tenens.
So, that is settled; but now to heal the other breach: Come, Major, the gentlemen of your cloth seldom bear malice, let me interpose between you and my son.
Your son-in-law, Sir Jacob, does deserve a castigation; but, on recollection, a cit would but sully my arms. I forgive him.
That's right; as a token of amity, and to celebrate our feast, let us call in the fiddles: Now if the Major had but his shoes, he might join in a country dance.
Sir Jacob, no shoes, a Major must be never out of his boots; always ready for action. Mrs. Sneak will find me light∣some enough.
What are all the vomen engaged; why then my Locum Tenens and I will jigg together. Forget and forgive, Major.
Freely.

Q.L: Nor be it said, that after all my toil,
I stain'd my regimentals by a broil.
To you I dedicate boots, sword, and shield,

SP.P: As harmless in the chamber as the field.
